meanings.def: to go down below the surface or towards the bottom of a liquid or soft substance
examples: The ship sank to the bottom of the sea.
The submarine sank after an explosion.
We're sinking!
sink into something The wheels started to sink into the mud.
The little boat sank beneath the waves.
It seemed as though the ship had sunk without trace.
Duane was in waist-deep and sinking fast.
He sank up to his knees in the mud.
Our feet sank deep into the soft sand as we walked.

meanings.def: to damage a boat or ship so that it goes below the surface of the sea, etc.
examples: The battleship was sunk by a torpedo.
Bombs sank all four carriers.
Five brothers all died when their ship was sunk.

meanings.def: to move downwards, especially by falling or sitting down
examples: I sank into an armchair.
She sank back into her seat, exhausted.
The old man had sunk to his knees.
He sank lower into his chair.
I sank gratefully into the warm, dry bed.
She sank gracefully down onto a cushion at his feet.
She sank to the ground, exhausted.

meanings.def: to move slowly downwards
examples: The sun was sinking in the west.
The sun had sunk below the horizon.
The foundations of the building are starting to sink.

meanings.def: to decrease in amount, volume, strength, etc.
examples: The pound has sunk to its lowest recorded level against the dollar.
He is clearly sinking fast (= getting weaker quickly and will soon die).
The project gradually sank into oblivion.
The airline industry is sinking under the weight of its losses.

meanings.def: to become quieter
examples: Her voice sank to a whisper.

meanings.def: to make a deep hole in the ground
examples: to sink a well/shaft/mine

meanings.def: to place something in the ground by digging
examples: to sink a post into the ground

meanings.def: to prevent somebody or somebody’s plans from succeeding
examples: I think I've just sunk my chances of getting the job.
If the car breaks down, we'll be sunk (= have serious problems).

meanings.def: to hit a ball into a hole in golf or snooker
examples: He sank a 12-foot putt to win the match.

meanings.def: to drink something quickly, especially a large amount of alcohol
examples: They sank three pints each in 10 minutes.

meanings.def: to be in a state of unhappiness or deep thought
examples: She just sat there, sunk in thought.

meanings.def: used to talk about people who leave an organization, a company, etc. that is having difficulties, without caring about the people who are left
used to say that somebody suddenly feels sad or depressed about something
examples: My heart sank when I saw how much work there was left.
She watched him go with a sinking heart.

meanings.def: to agree to forget about your disagreements
examples: We need to sink our differences and present a united opposition to the plan.

meanings.def: an unpleasant feeling that you get when you realize that something bad has happened or is going to happen
examples: I had a horrible sinking feeling when I saw the ambulance outside the house.

meanings.def: to be in a situation where you will either succeed by your own efforts or fail completely
examples: The new students were just left to sink or swim.
In a situation like this, you either sink or swim.

meanings.def: to have such low moral standards that you do something very bad
examples: Stealing from your friends? How could you sink so low?
I can't believe that anyone would sink to such depths.
With this article the newspaper has sunk to a new low.

meanings.def: to behave in a worse way than ever before
examples: The government has stooped to an all-time low with this policy.
Reality TV has sunk to new lows.

examples: Don't just leave your dirty plates in the sink!
I felt chained to the kitchen sink (= I had to spend all my time doing jobs in the house).
Put the dishes in the sink.
She filled the sink with hot water.
She was at the sink, washing the dishes.
The kitchen had a double sink.

a very large number of things, probably more than is necessary
